awd_abstract_narration:
In the past several years, cyber-crime and cyber-breaches have exploded, due to the increase in commerce conducted on the Internet, as well as increasing quantities of sensitive information being stored in databases that can be accessed by outside parties.  In addition, cyber-criminals have advanced, not only employing technical acumen but also preying on human error by using sophisticated techniques like phishing. To address these challenges, the Northeast Big Data Innovation Hub (NEBDIH) will convene two workshops to bring together experts from academia, government, and industry in the fields of insurance, cybersecurity, data science, and policy. The ultimate goal is to develop a collaborative model (e.g., a cross sector consortium) that will help to define the frequency and economic/social severity related to successful attacks, and to begin to develop baselines for measuring and managing cyber risk more effectively. 
 
NEBDIH will seek to gather leading academic, government, risk management, general industry and healthcare participants, whose mission will be to identify, quantify, and to help mitigate risk associated with cyber-related criminal activity. The workshops will serve as a forum for these experts to collaborate on: 1) better understanding and defining the interrelated cybersecurity landscape across sectors, and 2) planning for the resources necessary to develop baselines for measuring and managing cybersecurity risk. Expected outcomes from these activities include developing a framework for filling the gaps in quantifying and managing cybersecurity risk across organizations and sectors.  This may take the form of an initiative that captures the best  of breed technologies, vendors, and best practices; captures a substantial portion of the data that is required, in aggregate, to make a cybersecurity risk assessment at multiple levels (by industry, by region, by company); provides the tools to make the data discoverable and interoperable; and provides a basic suite of tools to allow for high level analysis of the data within the context of cybersecurity risk.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The Cybersecurity Risk Conference project, funded by NSF award #1748395, met and exceeded the original goals, achieving significant results beyond the initial scope. This Cybersecurity Risk Conference project is a key element of the Cybersecurity Risk Initiative led by the Northeast Big Data Innovation Hub (NEBDHub) headquartered at Columbia University.

The initial scope of this project was to convene two workshops to bring together experts from academia, government, and industry in the fields of cybersecurity, data science, insurance, technology, and policy to collaborate and define the interrelated cybersecurity landscape across sectors. These workshops were envisioned to facilitate the planning and building of resources necessary to develop baselines for measuring and managing cybersecurity risk. 

The first Cybersecurity Risk Workshop was held in July 2019 at the RiskEcon (R) Lab for Decision Metrics @ Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences New York University. The convened experts explored the development of a contextual taxonomy and framework to describe and understand cyber-physical security risks. Particular focus was given to vulnerabilities in commercial and industrial Internet of Things (IoT).

The second workshop was the Cybersecurity as Big Data Science Interactive Virtual Workshop held in April 2021. The objective of the workshop was to envision data science tools and techniques to improve cybersecurity risk analysis and mitigate threats. 

The 2021 workshop led to an opportunity to partner with Dr. S. Jay Yang, a cybersecurity and artificial intelligence/machine learning (AI/ML) professor and researcher at the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT), to extend the broader impact of this award to students and future cybersecurity leaders. Dr. Yang was granted a subaward funded through a No Cost Extension (NCE) to develop a "Cross-Organization Data Science for Cybersecurity Risk Assessment: Student Summer Program with Real-world Data Analytics" in 2022. Through his leadership, we engaged five undergraduates and one graduate student to explore data science approaches for cross-organizational cyberthreats and risk assessments. Several student papers and presentations were generated and presented at various pertinent venues, including the following:

  • Cross-Organizational Continual Learning of Cyber Threat Models, Poster Paper, 2022 Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC 2022), December 7-9, 2022, Austin TX, USA. Authors: Chanel Cheng and S. Jay Yang.

  • Translating Cybersecurity Descriptions into Interpretable MITRE Tactics using Transfer Learning, Poster Paper, 2022 Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC 2022), December 7-9, 2022, Austin TX, USA. Authors: Reza Fayyazi, Steve Wufeng, Pradumna Gautam, and S. Jay Yang. 

  • Data-driven Pattern Analysis and Continual Learning of Cyber Attacks across Organizations, webinar presentation to the NSF Big Data Innovation Hubs Data Sharing and Cyberinfrastructure Working Group, October 7, 2022, by Chanel Cheng and Serena Yang.

  • A Data Driven Approach to Cyber Risk and Threat Assessment, presentation to Duke University STINGAR team, September 23, 2022, by Serena Yang and Wei-Ting Chen.

  • Cross-Organizational Continual Learning of Cyber Threat Models, presentation at the NEBDHub Inaugural Student Research Symposium, January 27, 2023, by Chanel Cheng. 

  • A Data-Driven Approach for Cross-organization Cyber Risk and Threat Assessment, presentation at the NEBDHub Inaugural Student Research Symposium, January 27, 2023, by Serena Yang.

An additional five virtual workshops were supported by this award in the 2021 Global Connected Healthcare Cybersecurity Virtual Workshop Series, co-sponsored by the NEBDHub and the Institute for Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE). These workshops convened experts in public health, medicine, technology, policy, insurance, government, nonprofits, academia, and industry, including professionals and students. These workshops resulted in better understanding and documenting of cybersecurity risks in the connected healthcare ecosystem, including technology standards and policy implications to address the risk and translation of valuable research into practice. The workshops' proceedings and output are available through the NEBDHub and IEEE websites with links to on-demand videos and written workshop breakout summaries written by Columbia University graduate students and IEEE interns. (https://nebigdatahub.org/call-for-participation-connected-healthcare-cybersecurity-workshops-2021/)

The NEBDHub Executive Director and PI for this cybersecurity risk conference award, Florence Hudson, is also collaborating with IEEE to develop a standard for clinical Internet of Things (IoT) data and device interoperability with TIPPSS - Trust, Identity, Privacy, Protection, Safety and Security. The purpose of TIPPSS is to protect humans, devices, and data from harm in the face of increasing cybersecurity risks. This IEEE collaboration addresses the goals of this award and extends the interest generated at the 2019 cybersecurity risk workshop on cyber-physical security risks related to IoT. Interest in TIPPSS is growing with the increased focus on security, privacy, and trust issues across many sectors. PI Hudson has been invited to present TIPPSS in multiple venues, increasing collaboration with government, academia, industry and technologists in cybersecurity, including:

  • Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) 5th Annual Data Summit, Sept 2022 [https://cmsdata.fbcevent.com/agenda]

  • Institute for Electrical and Electronic Engineers (IEEE) Sensors Conference, Nov 2022   [https://2022.ieee-sensorsconference.org/presenter/florence-hudson/]

  • IEEE 8th World Forum on Internet of Things, Nov 2022 [https://wfiot2022.iot.ieee.org/woie-03/]

  • The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Advanced Communications Technology Working Group, Nov 2022


Last Modified: 05/31/2023
Modified by: Florence D Hudson
